fields.descriptive_line: Samuel Palmer's silver spectacles in a case. Great Britain. 19th century.

fields.name: Exhibition of Drawings, Etchings & Woodcuts by Samuel Palmer and other Disciples of William Blake

fields.physical_description: Pair of silver spectacles in case.
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, room 514a, case 19, shelf 21
fields.exhibition_history:
Exhibition of Drawings, Etchings & Woodcuts by Samuel Palmer and other Disciples of William Blake (Victoria and Albert Museum 20/10/1926-31/12/1926)
Samuel Palmer. Vision and Landscape (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York 07/03/2006-28/05/2006)
Samuel Palmer. Vision and Landscape (British Museum 21/10/2005-22/01/2006)
fields.bibliography: Vaughan, William, Elizabeth E. Barker and Colin Harrison, eds. Samuel Palmer 1805-1881: Vision and Landscape. London: The British Museum Press, 2005. 256 p., ill. (chiefly col.). Catalogue of the exhibition held at the British Museum, 12 October 2005 – 22 January 2006. ISBN 0714126411. Cat. no. 64, p.136, illus. The full text of the entry is as follows: ‘64 Samuel Palmer’s silver spectacles, 1819-20 Lit: V&A 1926, 18 London, Victoria and Albert Museum, E. 3979-1923; presented to the V&A by A.H. Palmer According to A.H. Palmer in the 1926 exhibition catalogue, his father ‘used these spectacles for nearly seventy years’ and wore them for all his work. Possibly they are the pair he had on in the portrait of him by Henry Walter of c.1835 (fig. 24, p.67), though the resemblance does not appear exact. A.H. Palmer’s claim that these spectacles were used by Palmer for all his work differs somewhat from the earlier account of them in Life and Letters: ‘A Pair of old-fashioned silver spectacles with very broad rims was used for distant objects; but on state occasions aforesaid, these were exchanged for spectacles of the ordinary pattern’ (L&L, p. 132). As Palmer was short-sighted, it would naturally be the case that he would wear glasses particularly to study distances. He also appears to have entertained a dialogue with his glasses, which seemed at times to offer him an alternative vision. In his lost sketchbook of 1823-4 he wrote: ‘The least bit of natural scenery reflected from one of my spectacle-glasses laughs me to scorn and hisses at me’ (L&L, p. 13). On another occasion he blames his glasses for under- mining his amorous aspirations, by disguising the ‘darting artillery of my eyes’ (see cat. 52). It was perhaps because of his obsession with glasses that Blake’s widow gave him Blake’s after the latter’s death. A.H. Palmer states that ‘Blake’s great, round steel-rimmed glasses, bleared by many years of use, were among my father’s very few personal treasures’ (L&L, p. 132).' Catalogue of an Exhibition of Drawings, Etchings & Woodcuts by Samuel Palmer and other Disciples of William Blake October 20 - December 31, 1926. London : Published under the authority of the Board of Education, 1926. Publication No. 178 E.I.D. The full text of the entry is as follows: 'DRAWINGS BY SAMUEL PALMER’S FRIENDS, AND HISTORICAL EXHIBITS [ … ] SAMUEL PALMER [ ... ] 18. Pair of silver spectacles in case, used by Samuel Palmer for nearly seventy years. Without the aid of these spectacles for near sight he was helpless, so far as his occupations were concerned (he hated the gimcrack, genteel pair in which he was photographed); and through them he saw the “Valley of Vision.” He alludes to parts of the Shoreham landscape reflected in one of his spectacle lenses as laughing him to scorn. Through them he saw Blake sign for him the extremely rare sheet of the Pastorals which is now placed on exhibition (See no.28). . . . Through them he gazed with almost equal enthusiasm at ancient Rome and the Villa D’Este cypresses, which, afterwards, he so often reproduced. But it was not long before the bitterest sorrows and disillusionments of life . . . fell upon him, and so dimmed were these lenses by tears, that he could scarcely see his little dying daughter when she tried to put her arms around his neck. Years afterwards, when he was finally crushed by the still greater grief for the death of his elder son, and was living through a dreadful winter, he wrote: - “I have been all day trying to see my work through tears.” He was working on “Wrecked at Home.” Without these spectacles he could not see the drawing clearly, and tears made them almost useless then, and often for many weeks afterwards. . . . His old nurse’s spectacles I still possess. They are of a far older and rougher type; and they have this point of interest. Wearing them she fumbled for her own favourite passages in the little volumes (No. 16) now sent to the Museum. – A.H.P. E.3979-1923. Presented by A. H. Palmer, Esq.'
fields.credit: Presented by A. H. Palmer, Esq.
fields.history_note: Spectacles and case owned by the artist Samuel Palmer.
